name: queer
content:
queer adjective
(SEX AND GENDER)
Add to word list
Add to word list
having or relating to a gender identity or a sexuality that does not fit society's traditional ideas about gender or sexuality: He says they use the word "queer" to include anyone who wants to be included (gay, bi, trans, whatever). They strongly identify with queer culture. Note: Queer can be offensive to some people. Only use this word if a person describes themselves in this way.
More examplesFewer examplesGrowing up, I knew in my heart I was queer.I find myself infuriated by this attitude of shame and guilt, as do many other queer men I’m sure. Derek Jarman was an English pioneer in queer cinema.Activists proudly claimed their queer identity.The queer community is inclusive and incorporates all these identities.
queer adjective
(STRANGE)
old-fashioned strange, unusual, or not expected: What a queer thing to say! I'm feeling rather queer (= ill), may I sit down? Synonyms
odd (STRANGE)
strange (UNUSUAL)

a person whose gender identity or sexuality does not fit society's traditional ideas about gender or sexuality: Critiques of mainstream queer representation from trans people and queers of colour played an important role in improving representation. Note: Queer can be offensive to some people. Only use this word if a person describes themselves in this way.
to change something so that it does not relate only to one gender, either male or female, or so that it no longer fits traditional ideas about gender or sexuality: Teenage boys with Instagram accounts are queering the cosmetics industry.
queer someone's pitch UK informal
to spoil a chance or an opportunity for someone, often intentionally: If she asks Dan for a pay rise before I do, it will probably queer my pitch. She'd accused him of queering her pitch. I certainly had no intention of queering his pitch. I'm quite sure you didn't mean to queer my pitch. I suspect he thinks I tried to queer his pitch, which I assuredly did not. Synonym
thwart
